page.title: 01GENERAL SURVEY OF THE AREA
page.content: Most of the designated area lies in the valley between the rivers Bourne and Kennet. This is an area of flat ground which had the river-gravel extracted before the 1939-45 war and is now used for cereal production. The village of Sulhamstead lies on the side of a hill in the south-east of the sector. The area has traditionally been important as part of the transport network of southern England. The river Kennet was used to transport goods to the river Thames until the canal was built in the 1790's. When the Great Western Railway was built in the 1840's the canal and river fell into disuse as a means of transport. Throughout this period the Great West Road has carried people and goods from London towards Bath and Bristol. In 1985 the A4 is the dominant feature of the area.
